title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!

Since this post doesn’t specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.

title: Mario Kart Blog
text:
library(tidyverse)
records <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2021/2021-05-25/records.csv')

Rows: 2334 Columns: 9
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (6): track, type, shortcut, player, system_played, time_period
dbl  (2): time, record_duration
date (1): date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

drivers <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2021/2021-05-25/drivers.csv')

Rows: 2250 Columns: 6
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (2): player, nation
dbl (4): position, total, year, records

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.2     ✔ readr     2.1.4
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.0
✔ ggplot2   3.4.3     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.2     ✔ tidyr     1.3.0
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

record_sum <- records |> group_by(track) |>
  summarise(avg_time = mean(time), n = n()) |>
  arrange(avg_time, desc = T) |>
  mutate(se = avg_time / n, 
         lb_se = avg_time - se,
         ub_se = avg_time + se)

record_sum

# A tibble: 16 × 6
   track                 avg_time     n    se lb_se ub_se
   <chr>                    <dbl> <int> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
 1 Mario Raceway             54.2   160 0.339  53.9  54.5
 2 Yoshi Valley              55.6   160 0.347  55.2  55.9
 3 Frappe Snowland           58.6   180 0.326  58.3  58.9
 4 Moo Moo Farm              61.1    81 0.754  60.3  61.8
 5 Choco Mountain            70.8   148 0.478  70.3  71.3
 6 D.K.'s Jungle Parkway     71.0   180 0.394  70.6  71.4
 7 Koopa Troopa Beach        72.4    89 0.814  71.6  73.2
 8 Luigi Raceway             74.3   147 0.506  73.8  74.8
 9 Kalimari Desert           76.9   169 0.455  76.5  77.4
10 Sherbet Land              78.1   143 0.546  77.6  78.7
11 Bowser's Castle           96.2    69 1.39   94.8  97.6
12 Banshee Boardwalk         97.4    83 1.17   96.3  98.6
13 Toad's Turnpike           98.9   196 0.504  98.4  99.4
14 Royal Raceway            109.    149 0.733 108.  110. 
15 Wario Stadium            132.    201 0.657 131.  133. 
16 Rainbow Road             205.    179 1.15  204.  206.
library(tidyverse)
record_sum |>
  mutate(track = fct_reorder(track, avg_time)) |>
  ggplot(aes(x = track, y = avg_time)) +
  geom_segment(aes(xend = track, yend = 0), color = "grey", size = 1.5) +
  geom_point(size=3, color="red", fill=alpha("orange"), shape=21, stroke=1.5) +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_minimal()

Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead.
How did the world records develop over time? Which track is the fastest? For which track did the world record improve the most? For how many tracks have shortcuts been discovered? When were shortcuts discovered? On which track does the shortcut save the most time? Which is the longest standing world record? Who is the player with the most world records? Who are recent players?

title: Mario Kart Blog
text:
Introduction
what data set are you working with?
what variables are you most interested in? How many observations are in your data set?
what is your question of interest?
where did you get the data from? (If possible, give a link to the data source).
github
what other pieces of context are important to explain to the reader?

title: Mario Kart Blog
text:
Primary Visualizations
choose an appropriate visualization, eliminate clutter, and focus attention as appropriate to answer your question of interest.
provide a written interpretation of each visualization you have, explaining what a reader should “take away” from each visualization.

title: Mario Kart Blog
text:
Conclusion and Wrap-Up
are there any flaws with your approach to analyzing the data you’ve selected?
are there future directions you would go if you had additional data or more time?

title: Mario Kart Blog
text:
Connection to Class Ideas
At the end of your write-up, you should connect your visualization(s) to ideas from class. In what ways would you argue your visualization(s) are effective ways of communicating information?

title: Test Post
text:
library(palmerpenguins)
library(tidyverse)
ggplot(penguins, aes(x = bill_length_mm)) +
  geom_histogram(color = "black", fill = "white")
